content.title: Child Adoption - Tamil Nadu
content.department: Social Welfare and Women Empowerment Department
content.beneficiary: Orphaned, abandoned, destitute and neglected children
content.details: The scheme 'Child Adoption - Tamil Nadu' was launched by the Social Welfare and Women Empowerment Department, Government of Tamil Nadu. The scheme aims to provide a family for orphaned, abandoned, destitute and neglected children. According to Central Adoption Resource Authority (CARA), 'adoption is a process by which a child who is abandoned / separated from biological parents, becomes the legitimate child of a new set of parents referred to as adoptive parents, with all the rights, privileges and responsibilities that are attached to this relationship'.
benefits: Accommodation, food, and health care to the babies till they are given in adoption.
A family to the destitute child and a child to childless parents.
Special adoption leave of 270 days is extended to female government servants of the state government who adopt a child below one year.
eligibility: The parents must have at least two years of a stable marital relationship.
The single prospective adoptive parents should be between 30-55 years of age.
An unmarried/single male persons are not eligible to adopt a girl child.
The parents should have adequate financial resources to upbring the child.
For a child up to 4 years old: Maximum composite age of the Prospective Adoptive Parents: 90 years.
For a single Prospective Adoptive Parent: Minimum age 25 years, maximum age 45 years.
For a child above 4 years up to 8 years old: Maximum composite age of the Prospective Adoptive Parents: 100 years.
For a single Prospective Adoptive Parent: Minimum age 25 years, maximum age 50 years.
For a child above 8 years up to 18 years old: Maximum composite age of the Prospective Adoptive Parents: 110 years.
For a single Prospective Adoptive Parent: Minimum age 25 years, maximum age 55 years.
content.application_process: Offline. Step 1: The interested applicant should visit (during office hours) the office State Adoption Resource Agency/Directorate of Social Defence/Concerned Probation Officer and request a hard copy of the prescribed format of the application form from the concerned staff. Step 2: In the application form, fill in all the mandatory fields, paste the passport-sized photograph (signed across, if required), and attach copies of all the mandatory documents (self-attest, if required). Step 3: Submit the duly filled and signed application form along with the documents to the State Adoption Resource Agency/Directorate of Social Defence/Concerned Probation Officer. Step 4: Request a receipt or acknowledgment from the concerned authority to whom the application has been submitted. Ensure that the receipt contains essential details such as the date and time of submission, and a unique identification number (if applicable).
documents_required: Proof of Residence (Aadhaar Card/Voter ID card/Passport/Driving License/Electricity Card).
Proof of Income of Last Year (Pay Bill/Income Tax Certificate).
Copy of Birth Certificate of the Prospective Adoptive Parents.

faqs.question: What kind of assistance is provided to children under this scheme?
faqs.answer: The scheme provides accommodation, food, and healthcare to the babies until they are adopted, and also facilitates the process of providing a family to the destitute child and a child to childless parents.

faqs.question: What are the eligibility criteria for prospective adoptive parents?
faqs.answer: Prospective Adoptive Parents must have a stable marital relationship of at least two years. Age and marital status criteria vary depending on the age of the child to be adopted.

faqs.question: What is the definition of child adoption according to CARA?
faqs.answer: According to the Central Adoption Resource Authority (CARA), adoption is a process by which a child who is abandoned or separated from biological parents becomes the legitimate child of a new set of parents (adoptive parents), with all the rights, privileges, and responsibilities attached to this relationship.

faqs.question: Which legal acts govern the process of adoption in India?
faqs.answer: The Hindu Adoption and Maintenance Act, 1956 (HAMA) and the Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection of Children) Act, 2015 govern adoption.

faqs.question: How is the child adoption process regulated?
faqs.answer: The adoption process is regulated by Non-Governmental Organisations and involves various authorities and agencies to ensure a thorough and legal process.

faqs.question: How many institutions are involved in implementing the adoption scheme?
faqs.answer: There are 23 institutions involved in implementing the adoption scheme.

faqs.question: Who should be contacted for information about adoption?
faqs.answer: Contact the State Adoption Resource Agency, the Directorate of Social Defence in Chennai, the concerned Probation Officer, or the 23 Licensed Specialized Adoption Agencies.

faqs.question: What documents need to be submitted for adoption?
faqs.answer: Documents include PAN Card/Passport, Proof of Residence, Proof of Income, Marriage Certificate and Photograph, Birth Certificate of the Prospective Adoptive Parents, Medical Certificate, and a Letter of identification from friends or relatives.

faqs.question: What happens if a prospective adoptive parent is found ineligible after submission of documents?
faqs.answer: If found ineligible, the prospective adoptive parent(s) will not be allowed to proceed with the adoption process and will be informed accordingly.

faqs.question: Are single males allowed to adopt a girl child?
faqs.answer: No, an unmarried or single male person is not eligible to adopt a girl child.
